headline: Tea Biscuits
description: This tea biscuits recipe is a particularly light treat thanks to lots of baking powder. These cookie-like snacks pair nicely with butter and jam.

video.description: Watch how to make this quick tea time treat.
video.name: Tea Biscuits

name: Tea Biscuits

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (205 degrees C). Grease a baking sheet.
Combine flour, baking powder, and salt in a bowl. Cut shortening in until mixture has a fine crumb texture. Stir in milk with a fork to make a soft dough.
Knead 8 to 10 times, and then roll out to a thickness of at least 1/2 inch. Cut into rounds with a cookie or biscuit cutter. Place on the baking sheet, and allow to rest for a few minutes.
Bake in the preheated oven for 12 to 15 minutes. Serve warm.

review.reviewBody: Quite good! Added a touch of sugar, took out a little salt. And put in about 1/2 c raisins. Reminded me of the tea biscuits at Tim Horton's (back when they made them).
I just brushed the tops with milk and enjoyed with my split pea soup

Made as written for the 1st batch. I love how well these came together, the dough was perfect (not too sticky or too dry) but overall these were waaaay TOO SALTY and the recipe needs to be adjusted. I added 1c of shredded cheddar cheese and dried green chives to later batches ðŸ˜‹
I followed recipe as it said no modifications..they turned out wonderful..
Pretty similar to the way my mom's tea biscuits taste. Love'em!

Easy recipe. I used 1/2 cup butter, plus another tablespoon-ish. I had to add more milk to my dough because it was too dry, probably a two tablespoons. I also added 1/2 cup sugar and 1 cup golden raisins. Baked at 400Â° for 12 mins. The biscuits were still pale on top but golden on the bottom. I used baking spray on one cookie sheet, a silpat on the other, and the baking spray yielded a slightly darker bottom.

I have made this 3 times using different ingredients based upon the reviews that I read. I tried half butter and half shortening, they were good but I prefer all shortening as it makes the biscuit very flaky which I love. I am not a raisin fan which attracted me to this recipe. This has become my go-to tea biscuit recipe.
Too much milk!!!!
The first time I made these I wasnâ€™t real happy but the second time I just made less than what the recipe said and they turned out perfect!
This is a fantastic recipe. I've made it numerous times in the past few years. I follow it as written except sometimes I add shredded cheddar to the dough. Turns out perfect every time! Thank you!!
Turned out perfect. I used buttermilk and butter
WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAY TOO MUCH BAKING SODA!!!!!!!

I didnâ€™t care for the taste of the shortening. I think theyâ€™d be good made with butter instead. Also the ones I cut out with a cookie cutter didnâ€™t rise much but the leftover dough that I dropped onto the pan rose nicely and were fluffier, so I would just make as drop biscuits next time.

Yes changes done from others comments:
Sifted flour, added 1/4 tsp dry active yeast and 1/4 cup raisins
Rest was the same.....very light and yummy.
first time trying the recipe. Totally simple. Turned out wonderful
I used butter instead of shortening. Was the best biscuit recipe I have had in years.
I love this recipe! The first time I made it I needed a recipe without butter. These plump so nicely in the oven and are great with sausage gravy. Family loves it! Thank you for such a great recipe!
Best tea biscuit recipe by far....just a little bit salty for me..I will add a little less salt next time.
These are great, I also use them on top of my chicken pot pie instead of pie dough, my family just love it.
I used whole wheat flour, they weren't at light as usual but it's ok. Enjoyed them greatly with my corn chowder!

Mine did not rise st all! I used a gluten free flour!
Could be the reason

Made this recipe as suggested then made my adjustments. I added 5 tsp of sugar to the dry mix and added a tsp of vanilla to the milk before adding to dry mix. Did not roll out - I just pressed with my fingers on a parchment sheet (no extra flour) then used a small round cookie cutter. Baked at 400 for 12min on parchment paper and an insulated cookie sheet. Recipe made a dozen and they were fabulous.

This is an amazing recipe! I didn't have shortening on hand so I used 1/2 cup butter, and I added 1/3 cup brown sugar, as per some of the review recommendations. The biscuits turned out AMAZING. I also didn't roll them out; after kneading, I would grab small balls of dough, flatten it a bit with my hand, and then cut the shape out. I got 10 biscuits, each about 2 inches in diameter from this recipe.

This recipe makes the perfect biscuits. I usually add a tablespoon of sugar, and add different types of cheeses when I make it. The best is probably medium or old cheddar. And it's super easy to make.

The texture of these was phenomenal, but the flavor was only ok. They had plenty of salt, but yet seemed just *okay*. I used an unflavored crisco, same as I typically use in my biscuits. I do believe it would have been improved with some bacon fat or butter flavored crisco.
My husband said he prefers my other recipe for biscuits - and I can't remember which one he's talking about! I've been trying out a few new ones lately! Ha!
*I followed another reviewers suggestion to try using seran wrap on a slightly damp counter - worked great! Eliminated the mess completely! I didn't even add flour :)

These turned out really good.. Phew!!! :) I only say that because I took a risk and doubled the recipe (needed double the amount that the original recipe makes) Of course I made some modifications ;) reduced the baking powder to half the amount, and I don't use shortening so I used butter instead (only had salted butter so I reduced the amount of salt to half of what is says originally). I have made biscuits many times and this is the recipe I like the most... So I highly recommend it! 
Thank you for sharing this recipe, Debbie.
I love the recipe. super easy. next time I will add cheese or something sweet.
I used butter instead of shortening and I had half n half instead of milk. They turned out really well, delicate and crumbling!

I found these tea biscuits very bland and salty despite it only calling for 1 tsp of salt. I tried them with some cheddar cheese and with jam. I brought some to my co-workers....Threw out the remainder of what I made. Very disappointed.

Great tea biscuits!! Only change I made was using butter instead of shorting, and added 1/2 cup of sugar ... next time I think I'll use 1/3 of a cup of sugar they were bit sweet and they go great with all jams !!
Used these in top of a chicken pot pie top mix. So good!
Cut salt in half

This is my go to basic t-biscuit recipe. I substitute cold butter for the shortening and often roll it out flat and add a slather of butter and cinnamon and brown sugar. Roll it up and cut into 1.5" slices. Bake in a 9x9 pan. Our family favorite cinnamon biscuit roll with cream cheese icing.
The biscuits were good but not quite what I expected. These could have been any off the shelf store variety in taste and texture. Again not bad just plain in my opinion.

They came out great. I added 3 table of sugar to recipe. They were a big hit. I also put each serving in a ball, split in half , flattened some & put both halves in a miuffin tin. Came out great. Roger

Great taste and texture. I usually use a buttermilk recipe but was out of buttermilk and found this recipe. The only changes I made were to sift the dry ingredients and I added a little extra milk to make the batter more moist. I will definitely make it again.
I Substituted with buttermilk, just because that's all I had, and 1 tsp. more baking powder, just because was afraid would be heavy. Came out fantastic. Light and fluffy. Great recipe!
I Substituted with buttermilk, just because that's all I had, and 1 tsp. more baking powder, just because was afraid would be heavy. Came out fantastic. Light and fluffy. Great recipe!
Awesome!!!!! these biscuits tasted awesome and flakey. just perfect with jam honey or tea. simply wonderful.

These are super simple and yummy biscuits. For a change I rolled out the dough and then spread with butter, cinnamon and brown sugar, then rolled it up and cut little cinnamon biscuits that turned out great!
Excellent texture!

Well, I never rate dishes i make. This one reminds me of my grandmother. From the southeast she made homemade biscuits quite often. This recipe is delicate the biscuits are rich and flaky. I made a double batch. It's quite superb. I also added goat cheese to one batch! With honey incredible biscuits!!

I make these for Christmas every year specially for my daughter because they are the only sweets she really likes. 

For people who are complaining that they are too crumbly if you wait until they are cool before touching them they don't practically disintegrate on you. If they do after cooling then you did something wrong. You need to nake sure you whip the batter long enough or they won't turn out well.
Quick and easy! Instead of rolling the dough out I just made 11 drop biscuits. I've eaten 5 so farâ€¦

Makes a perfect tea biscuit. my 9 year old daughter made this recipe as it is so simple.They are a perfect texture..not too dry and not doughy. Great with honey or jam and even just plain!We shaped outs into snowmen for a more festive fun biscuit to eat.

This is a great, quick recipe. Only thing to note is the 'resting' time before baking. I allowed 5 minutes, but I think 10 or more might have allowed the biscuits to rise a little higher. Even so, these were delicious and I will definitely make them again!
These were the best tea biscuits I have ever made! Tasty, light, smooth texture! I used 1/4 cup shortening and 1/4 cup margarine. I will use this recipe from now on!

These are great!

Although I used butter instead of shortening.
Overall, definitely a recipe I would recommend, and make time after time.
This is the recipe that my mom used to teach me how to make these biscuits to accompany homemade soup. Delicious as usual, but it always spends on how fresh the baking powder is.
My 8 year old followed the recipe and the results were fantastic! Quick and easy cooking project.

This is my ONLY tea biscuit recipe because these turn out AMAZING every single time!!! Thanks soooo much for sharing!!! I make these for little ones by using a shot glass to cut the dough as well as leaving the dough a bit thicker so the puff right up!!
Easy peasy recipe. Everyone loved it including me.

I have made these biscuits several times and I've always had excellent results. It is one of my go to recipes when I want a recipe I know is going to please. Today is different in that I used organic for all of the ingredients including organic coconut shortening. The results were just the same, wonderful. Next time I will try using my own organic milled flour and see what happens. I'm sure they will be heavy but I'm pretty sure they'll still be great. Thanks for a great recipe!
tooo much baking powder

I was looking for a simple, basic biscuit recipe to make with my 6 year old grand-daughter - we changed two things. We used all butter and used the drop method rather than rolling out and cutting them. The recipe makes a good, basic tender biscuit. Someone else mentioned that too much handling makes them tough - that is exactly what I learned over the many years I have been making biscuits.

Followed others advise and used half butter half shortning. I added perhaps 1/2 c cheddar chunks and tablespoon fresh spicy oregano snipped in pieces. Next time I will pat out and not roll my hubby likes them thicker Very tender

Made these tonight for strawberry shortcake. I cut the salt in half added 3 table spoons of sugar and increased the milk to 1 cup. They mixed well and I dropped the dough rather than rolled it out. They turned out good. However in the future I am going to reduce the salt to 1/4 of a teaspoon and reduce the baking powder as well. With a little tweaking I am confident this will be a family favorite.
I substituted unsalted butter for the shortening and got 10 x 3 inch biscuits. Nice and fluffy and moist. I will definitely make these again.
Way to much Baking Powder, the taste was off and I couldn't get it right. I will not make it again.
Followed the recipe exactly. Nice biscuit. A little dry which is how biscuits are supposed to be
I make these about twice a week and they turn out beautiful every time. Perfectly crumbly & melt in your mouth good. I add up to 1/2 cup sugar for shortcake.
They are very good! I added two table spoons of sugar too them and they are delicious.

Even after heeding the warnings about the baking powder being overpowering ... I figured I'd run the risk of going 50% less baking powder even with that amount.... the baking powder was STILL overpowering...

HUGE HIT!!. Super simple! I mixed up the dry ingredients and used butter. Put it in the fridge until ready to bake. Then added in the milk and let it rest about 10 minutes. Rolled it out lightly and made about 15 biscuits. Next time would roll a little thicker.
I doubled the recipe and used butter. Perfect. Absolutely delicious.
This was my first time making tea biscuits. The recipe was easy to follow and they turned out great. Light and fluffy. I will add slightly less salt next time.
Great recipe, very simple. I used butter instead of shortening, and they turned out very flakey, I think next time I'll use a bit less salt, but overall, good biscuits.
Did 1/4 butter 1/4 shortening. Made 12 biscuits didn't roll out dough, just flattened dough with my hands

Very nice basic recipe that you can experiment with. I followed the recipe exactly and they turned out amazing. Only problem was, we don't eat processed foods, so they are a touch too salty for me, but that is my taste. Wonderful recipe, thank you!
Delicious, I made these just this morning and they were perfect!
Crispy outside with soft, warm and flaky inside, paired wonderfully with a hot bowl of soup, tea and jams! We needed to add a little extra milk, just to bring it all together, but still lovely.
Loved them! Fast and delicious.
Made it according to the recipe and they came out great... Very easy to make...
This recipe was awful, biscuits turned out flat and way too dry. I would not recommend this one.
This is how my mother made them. I love these for breakfast.
Super easy to make and delicious! Will definitely make again!
delicious recipe! Reminds me of my childhood and eating my Teetie's tea biscuits!
Absolutely yummy! Thank you so very much!!!
Delicious.

The teaspoon of salt was just too much :/ 
These are really hard to eat with all that salt.
Super easy to make and they always come out great.
Second time with great results. Fist time I added 1 cup of grated cheese second time I tablespoon dried rosemary.
I've tried quite a few biscuit recipes and these managed to impress all 4 of my kids and my husband. Not an easy thing to do! Great for dinner or with preserves and tea.
fantastic

I was worried because I had no shortening. So I used coconut oil instead and was delighted. I've used butter instead of shortening in other recipes and wasn't as happy with that substitution as I was with coconut oil.
I love this recipe. Please be sure to use baking powder and not baking soda; they are two different things; one is very salty; the other is not.
Golden outside, flakey inside. Use at least 1/2 shortening (the rest butter) for a smooth, easy to cut-out dough. Rose beautifully! I think you MUST be certain oven is hot.

Great recipe, can't mess It up!
Tastes great with soups on cold days!!
I made homemade tea biscuits the other night for the first time, I used this recipe. They were very easy to make and tasted awesome! (I only had unsalted butter to use at the time)
I made homemade tea biscuits the other night for the first time, I used this recipe. They were very easy to make and tasted awesome! (I only had unsalted butter to use at the time)
Way too salty, but overall the texture was good.
I love these! I use less salt and coconut oil instead of shortening and it's perfection! (My sister also substitutes the milk for almond milk and they too are good!
Way way to much baking powder
substitute bacon drippings for shortning, tastes great!
Delicious. Used grated frozen butter instead of shortening

Those were SUPER easy!! I whipped 'm up in 10 mins to go with my pot roast. I followed the recipe and added a few shakes of dried chives and about 2/3 cup of shredded Colby Jack cheese. I do not have a biscuit cutter so I just used the cap of my cooking spray...worked like a charm! :)
Very dry and there is too much baking powder, which made them too salty. They would probably be better if the recipe used butter instead of shortening.
Amazing light, flaky biscuits, I added more flour however and used the knead cycle on my bread machine.
